Release scenarios were modeled using EPAs RMP*Comp, a browser-based software, and then evaluated using the EPA developed Mapping Applications for Response, Planning, and Local Operational Tasks (MARPLOT) 5.1.1 software.

The alternative scenario for a covered Program 3 process must be one that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.

The offsite consequence analysis identifies that the facilitys worst-case release scenario for Program 1 flammables (e.g., butane) involves a release from a single storage trailer. The scenario assumes that 12,677 pounds of butane is released, the entire amount vaporizes within 10 minutes, and the total quantity is involved in a vapor cloud explosion. The distance at which the explosion overpressure equals the regulatory endpoint of one pound per square inch (psi) was determined to be 0.20 miles. No public or environmental receptors were identified in this scenario.

The offsite consequence analysis identifies that the facilitys worst-case release scenario for Program 3 flammables involves a release from the largest single storage container of propane. The scenario assumes the entire propane storage quantity of 208,800 pounds is released, the entire amount vaporizes within 10 minutes, and the total quantity is involved in a vapor cloud explosion. The distance at which the explosion overpressure equals the regulatory endpoint of one pound per square inch (psi) was determined to be 0.50 miles. Residences and commercial/industrial areas were identified as public receptors within the affected area, but no environmental receptors were identified within the worst-case distance to the endpoint. 

The alternative release scenario is based on a safety relief valve failure, which causes overpressure or overfill of a propane bulk storage tank that results in a vapor cloud explosion. The scenario estimated a release rate of 1,938 pounds per minute for five minutes, based on a standard cubic feet per minute flowrate of a four-valve 2.5 multiport re

pylene, and butane is 10,000 pounds. Worthington exceeds the threshold quantities for each of the listed substances and is therefore required to develop and implement a Risk Management Plan (RMP) under 40 CFR 68. The RMP must also be submitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) using the RMP*eSubmit program found under EPAs Central Data Exchange (CDX) online submittal platform.

The purpose of this written RMP is to provide updates to a previously written plan prepared by Foth in 2019. Updated information includes new facility contacts, updated regulated substance quantities, storage locations, updated process program level determinations, as well as updates required by the RMP Reconsideration Rule. 

Based on an evaluation performed by Foth, in conjunction with Worthington personnel, it was determined that the facilitys process associated with butane meets Program Level 1 criteria and the facilitys process associated with propane and propylene meets Program Level 3 criteria. 

Based on the EPAs General Risk Management Program Guidance, a facility shall conduct one worst-case analysis to qualify a process for Program 1. Additionally, one worst-case analysis and one alternative release scenario is to be conducted for all processes involving Program 3 flammables. An alternative scenario analysis is not required for each flammable substance above the threshold. 

For the worst-case scenario involving a release of a regulated flammable substance, the facility must assume that the quantity of the flammable substance is released into a vapor cloud and that a vapor cloud explosion results. Additionally, they must estimate the distance to an endpoint to an overpressure level of one pound per square inch (psi) from the explosion of the vapor cloud. Alternative release scenarios involving flammable substances must use either overpressure of one pound per square inch (psi) for vapor cloud explosions, radiant heat of five kilowatts per square meter (

The Worthington Cylinders Wisconsin, LLC (Worthington) facility is located at 300 East Breed Street in Calumet County, Chilton, Wisconsin, 53014. The facility manufactures steel canisters and cylinders which are then filled with a mixture of flammable gases consisting of propane and propylene. Bulk delivery of propane and propylene occurs by either commercial truck or tanker rail car. The gases are transferred to bulk storage tanks prior to the container filling process. Facility warehouses store bulk quantities of flammable gas-filled canisters and cylinders prior to offsite shipment. Additionally, Worthington accepts shipments of small-volume butane-filled utility lighters that are repackaged and stored onsite within storage trailers.

The facilitys bulk propane system includes:
(1) 60,000-gallon tank
(2) 30,000-gallon tank
Fill and storage locations

The facilitys bulk propylene system includes:
(1) 30,000-gallon tank
(1) 6,000-gallon tank 
(2) 60,000-gallon railcars
Fill and storage locations

The facilitys butane system includes:
(9) Storage trailers with approximately 12,677-gallons of butane per trailer contained in small-volume lighters 

The fill and storage locations referenced above include the fill building, warehouse zones 101, 102, and 103, the pick and pack area, east warehouse sections a, b, and c, as well as nine storage trailers. Within the fill and storage locations, cylinders are filled with a mixture of propane and propylene and then stored prior to offsite shipment. Butane is stored in small-volume utility lighters throughout the nine (9) storage trailers. Approximately 2,639,475 pounds of propane, 1,283,505 pounds of propylene, and 114,092 pounds of butane are stored onsite.
